title:
The infrared behavior of Landau gauge Yang-Mills theory in d=2, 3 and 4
  dimensions

title_detail.value:
The infrared behavior of Landau gauge Yang-Mills theory in d=2, 3 and 4
  dimensions

summary:
We develop a general power counting scheme for the infrared limit of Landau
gauge SU(N) Yang-Mills theory in arbitrary dimensions. Employing a skeleton
expansion, we find that the infrared behavior is qualitatively independent of
the spacetime dimension d. In the cases d=2, 3 and 4 even the quantitative
results for the infrared exponents of the vertices differ only slightly.
Therefore, corresponding lattice simulations provide interesting qualitative
information for the physical case. We furthermore find that the loop integrals
depend only weakly on the numerical values of the IR exponents.

We develop a general power ounting s heme for the infrared limit of Landau gauge SU (N ) YangMills theory in arbitrary dimensions. Employing a skeleton expansion, we nd that the infrared
behavior is qualitatively independent of the spa etime dimension d. In the ases d = 2, 3 and 4
even the quantitative results for the infrared exponents of the verti es dier only slightly. Therefore,
orresponding latti e simulations provide interesting qualitative information for the physi al ase.
We furthermore nd that the loop integrals depend only weakly on the numeri al values of the IR
exponents.

The infrared (IR) regime of Yang-Mills theory determines the fundamental non-perturbative properties of the non-Abelian gauge dynami s. In parti ular, the IR limit of Greens fun tions
of the olored elds are likely onne ted to the problem of onnement as demonstrated within the
s enarios of Kugo-Ojima [1℄ and Gribov-Zwanziger [2, 3℄. Due to the intri ate nature of the problem an
investigation via all available methods is desirable. Su h ombined eorts via Dyson-S hwinger equations
(DSE) [4, 5, 6, 7℄, renormalization group (RG) te hniques [8℄ and latti e gauge theory studies [9℄ led
during the last years to a oherent pi ture of the infrared regime in Landau gauge. Hereby, in the
ontinuum approa hes, the IR s aling limit of general Greens fun tions in four spa etime dimensions has
been determined [10℄. It exhibits, as argued for in [11℄, a dominan e of the gauge xing part of the a tion,
i.e. the Faddeev-Popov ghost. A simultaneous analysis of DSE and RG methods allowed furthermore to
show that this IR xpoint is unique [12℄.
The Greens fun tions of Yang-Mills theory in Landau gauge are studied extensively on the latti e,
see e.g. [9℄. These analyses show the IR in rease of the ghost dressing fun tion required in both the
Kugo-Ojima and the Gribov-Zwanziger s enario, as well as the IR s aling of the gluon dressing fun tion
in a ordan e with DSE and RG analyses. The inuen e of nite volume orre tions has been studied
within DSE analyses on ompa t manifolds [13℄ whi h agree qualitatively with the nite IR limit of
urrent latti e results. However, a onrmation that even the gluon propagator vanishes weakly in the IR,
whi h is ne essary in the Gribov-Zwanziger s enario, has not yet been possible in four-dimensional latti e
simulations due to the large latti e sizes required to probe the IR regime. The situation is similar for the
important but even harder determination of the s aling behavior of vertex fun tions or the quantitative
extra tion of IR exponent. Lower dimensional latti es ould allow to test qualitative aspe ts of these
Greens fun tions in a substantially simpler setting. Naturally, su h a surrogate study requires that the
generi features are identi al to those in four-dimensional spa etime. Re ent latti e studies in two [14℄
and three spa etime dimensions [15℄ indeed suggest a power-law behavior similar to the four dimensional
ase.
SU (N ) Yang-Mills theory in three spa etime dimensions is also relevant from two other points of
view. In the high temperature limit only the lowest Matsubara mode ontributes, leading to a dimensional
redu tion and thus to an ee tive eld theory in three dimensions. The qualitative aspe ts of this ee tive
theory, in parti ular with regard to its onning nature, may be overed by ordinary three-dimensional
gauge theory [16℄. Similarly, Yang-Mills theory in the anoni al quantization approa h in Coulomb gauge

These results motivate to study the dependen e of the infrared limit on the parameters of the theory in
more detail. It will turn out that the infrared solution of Yang-Mills theory is determined by the spa etime
dimension d and one parameter κ that determines the IR exponents of propagators and verti es. In this
work we establish a manifest power ounting s heme for general vertex fun tions of Landau gauge YangMills theory in arbitrary dimensions. We nd qualitatively similar results as in the four-dimensional
analysis given in [10℄. Furthermore we dis uss the dependen e of the Dyson-S hwinger equations on the
infrared s aling parameter κ. In four dimensions it takes a value κ ≈ 0.595 within an approximation
based on the propagator DSEs and using a bare ghost-gluon vertex. A possible dressing of this vertex
ould hange this value slightly [6℄. Therefore we study to what extent these dynami al building blo ks
in the DSEs depend on κ, employing an analysis of the IR-dominant integrals.
IR exponents for arbitrary d: In the following we will perform a s aling analysis for the IR regime
of Yang-Mills theory in arbitrary dimensions. In ontrast to the generi IR limit we study the limit
where the oupling g is kept xed and has no inherent s aling dependen e. Instead in dimensions other
than four it xes the fundamental s ale of the theory. This limit is more dire tly a essible in latti e
simulations and has been analyzed in [14, 15℄. A similar IR analysis has previously been performed for
the physi ally important ase d = 4 in refs. [10, 12℄. Although the s aling in arbitrary dimension may be
abstra ted from these results via the onsideration of the appropriate anoni al s aling dimensons, we
hose to give a on ise and nevertheless self- ontained derivation of the general s aling relations and refer
the reader to the orresponding work for details. We note, that our analysis is immediately appli able
to the gauge se tor of QCD sin e losed quark loops are IR-suppressed due to the nite urrent quark
masses [18℄ and therefore there are no quark ontributions to purely bosoni Greens fun tions in the IR
regime. This has been veried in ref. [19℄.
Analog to the orresponding analysis in four dimensions [10℄, the starting point for the IR analysis is the
non-renormalization of the ghost-gluon vertex in Landau gauge [20℄, whi h implies a nite vertex in the
infrared [10℄. This property depends purely on the transversality of the gluon propagator and is, as long
as the ghost-gluon s attering kernel is not strongly IR-divergent, therefore valid in arbitrary dimensions.
